Its intrinsic properties, including high cell permeability, the ability to easily cross both the blood brain and placenta barriers, and its role as an endogenous reservoir of free radical scavengers (with indirect extra activities), confer it beneficial uses as an adjuvant in the biomedical field. Melatonin can exert its effects by acting through specific cellular receptors on the plasma membrane, similar to other hormones, or through receptor-independent mechanisms that involve complex molecular cross talk with other players. There is increasing evidence regarding the extraordinary beneficial effects of melatonin, also via exogenous administration. Here, we summarize molecular pathways in which melatonin is considered a master regulator, with attention to cell death and inflammation mechanisms from basic, translational and clinical points of view in the context of newborn care.","datePublished":"2019-04-08T00:00:00Z","dateModified":"2019-04-08T00:00:00Z","pageStart":"1","pageEnd":"12","license":"http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/","sameAs":"https://doi.org/10.1038/s41419-019-1556-7","keywords":["Cell biology","Medical research","Life Sciences","general","Biochemistry","Cell Biology","Immunology","Cell Culture","Antibodies"],"image":["https://media.springernature.com/lw1200/springer-static/image/art 3A10.1038 2Fs41419-019-1556-7/MediaObjects/41419_2019_1556_Fig1_HTML.png","https://media.springernature.com/lw1200/springer-static/image/art 3A10.1038 2Fs41419-019-1556-7/MediaObjects/41419_2019_1556_Fig2_HTML.png","https://media.springernature.com/lw1200/springer-static/image/art 3A10.1038 2Fs41419-019-1556-7/MediaObjects/41419_2019_1556_Fig3_HTML.png","https://media.springernature.com/lw1200/springer-static/image/art 3A10.1038 2Fs41419-019-1556-7/MediaObjects/41419_2019_1556_Fig4_HTML.png"],"isPartOf":{"name":"Cell Death   Disease","issn":["2041-4889"],"volumeNumber":"10"," type":["Periodical","PublicationVolume"]},"publisher":{"name":"Nature Publishing Group UK","logo":{"url":"https://www.springernature.com/app-sn/public/images/logo-springernature.png"," type":"ImageObject"}," type":"Organization"},"author":[{"name":"Anna Tarocco","affiliation":[{"name":"University of Ferrara","address":{"name":"Department of Morphology, Surgery and Experimental Medicine, Section of Pathology, Oncology and Experimental Biology, Laboratory for Technologies of Advanced Therapies (LTTA), University of Ferrara, Ferrara, Italy"," type":"PostalAddress"}," type":"Organization"},{"name":"University Hospital S. Its intrinsic properties, including high cell permeability, the ability to easily cross both the blood  8211;brain and placenta barriers, and its role as an endogenous reservoir of free radical scavengers (with indirect extra activities), confer it beneficial uses as an adjuvant in the biomedical field. Melatonin can exert its effects by acting through specific cellular receptors on the plasma membrane, similar to other hormones, or through receptor-independent mechanisms that involve complex molecular cross talk with other players. There is increasing evidence regarding the extraordinary beneficial effects of melatonin, also via exogenous administration. Here, we summarize molecular pathways in which melatonin is considered a master regulator, with attention to cell death and inflammation mechanisms from basic, translational and clinical points of view in the context of newborn care."/   meta name "prism.issn" content "2041-4889"/   meta name "prism.publicationName" content "Cell Death  amp; class "c-article-body"   section aria-labelledby "Abs1" data-title "Abstract" lang "en"  div class "c-article-section" id "Abs1-section"  h2 class "c-article-section__title js-section-title js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id "Abs1" Abstract /h2  div class "c-article-section__content" id "Abs1-content"  p Melatonin, more commonly known as the sleep hormone, is mainly secreted by the pineal gland in dark conditions and regulates the circadian rhythm of the organism. Its intrinsic properties, including high cell permeability, the ability to easily cross both the blood brain and placenta barriers, and its role as an endogenous reservoir of free radical scavengers (with indirect extra activities), confer it beneficial uses as an adjuvant in the biomedical field. Melatonin can exert its effects by acting through specific cellular receptors on the plasma membrane, similar to other hormones, or through receptor-independent mechanisms that involve complex molecular cross talk with other players. There is increasing evidence regarding the extraordinary beneficial effects of melatonin, also via exogenous administration. Here, we summarize molecular pathways in which melatonin is considered a master regulator, with attention to cell death and inflammation mechanisms from basic, translational and clinical points of view in the context of newborn care. /p  /div  /div  /section   section aria-labelledby "inline-recommendations" data-title "Inline Recommendations" class "c-article-recommendations" js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id "Sec3" Introduction /h2  div class "c-article-section__content" id "Sec3-content"  p Melatonin ( i N /i -acetyl-5-methoxytryptamine) is a ubiquitous molecule present in nature that carries out many functions sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 1" title "Amaral, F. G. D.  amp; Cipolla-Neto, J. A brief review about melatonin, a pineal hormone. Arch. Endocrinol. Metab. 62, 472 479 (2018)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR1" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e525" 1 /a  /sup , manifesting enormous versatility and diversity. More commonly known as the sleep hormone, melatonin also has antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antiapoptotic, and many other crucial properties sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 2" title "Garcia-Navarro, A. et al. Cellular mechanisms involved in the melatonin inhibition of HT-29 human colon cancer cell proliferation in culture. J. Pineal Res. 43, 195 205 (2007)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR2" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e529" 2 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 3" title "Tan, D. X., Manchester, L. C., Esteban-Zubero, E., Zhou, Z.  amp; Reiter, R. J. Melatonin as a potent and inducible endogenous antioxidant: synthesis and metabolism. Molecules 20, 18886 18906 (2015)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR3" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e532" 3 /a  /sup . In mammals, this multitasking indolamine is synthesized in the pineal gland in a circadian manner in response to the photoperiodic information received via the retinohypothalamic pathway sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 4" title "Claustrat, B., Brun, J.  amp; Chazot, G. The basic physiology and pathophysiology of melatonin. Sleep. Med. Rev. 9, 11 24 (2005)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR4" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e536" 4 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 5" title "Pandi-Perumal, S. R. et al. Melatonin: Nature s most versatile biological signal? FEBS J. 273, 2813 2838 (2006)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR5" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e539" 5 /a  /sup . It is directly released into the bloodstream, where it is distributed to all tissues sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 6" title "Cheung, R. T. et al. Preclinical evaluation of pharmacokinetics and safety of melatonin in propylene glycol for intravenous administration. J. Pineal Res. 41, 337 343 (2006)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR6" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e543" 6 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 7" title "Esposito, E.  amp; Cuzzocrea, S. Antiinflammatory activity of melatonin in central nervous system. Curr. Neuropharmacol. 8, 228 242 (2010)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR7" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e546" 7 /a  /sup . Melatonin has two important functional groups that determine its specificity and amphiphilicity: the 5-methoxy group and the N-acetyl side chain. In particular, due to its amphiphilic characteristics, melatonin can diffuse and easily cross all morpho-physiological barriers, such as the placenta or the blood brain barrier sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 8" title "Carloni, S., Facchinetti, F., Pelizzi, N., Buonocore, G.  amp; Balduini, W. Melatonin acts in synergy with hypothermia to reduce oxygen-glucose deprivation-induced cell death in rat hippocampus organotypic slice cultures. Neonatology 114, 364 371 (2018)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR8" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e551" 8 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 9" title "Motta-Teixeira, L. C. et al. The absence of maternal pineal melatonin rhythm during pregnancy and lactation impairs offspring physical growth, neurodevelopment, and behavior. Horm. Behav. 105, 146 156 (2018)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR9" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e554" 9 /a  /sup , and it can enter all cells of the body, influencing the function of a variety of tissues sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 10" title "Tan, D. X. et al. Identification of highly elevated levels of melatonin in bone marrow: its origin and significance. Biochim. Biophys. Acta 1472, 206 214 (1999)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR10" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e558" 10 /a  /sup . Pineal synthesis is timed by the suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus, depending on the light dark cycle over a 24-h period sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 5" title "Pandi-Perumal, S. R. et al. Melatonin: Nature s most versatile biological signal? FEBS J. 273, 2813 2838 (2006)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR5" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e562" 5 /a  /sup . Melatonin is mainly produced during the dark phase, and the maximal plasma concentration of this serotonin-derived hormone usually occurs 4 5 h after darkness onset sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 11" title "Chattoraj, A., Liu, T., Zhang, L. S., Huang, Z.  amp; Borjigin, J. Melatonin formation in mammals: in vivo perspectives. Rev. Endocr. Metab. Disord. 10, 237 243 (2009)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR11" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e566" 11 /a  /sup . Light stimulus activates melanopsin breakdown in retinal photoreceptive ganglion cells that, via the retinohypothalamic pathway, induce the inhibition of melatonin synthesis sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 12" title "Reiter, R. J. Pineal melatonin: cell biology of its synthesis and of its physiological interactions. Endocr. Rev. 12, 151 180 (1991)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR12" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e570" 12 /a  /sup ; as a consequence, during the daily light period, its level is low or even undetectable sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 13" title "Dominguez-Rodriguez, A., Abreu-Gonzalez, P.  amp; Reiter, R. J. Clinical aspects of melatonin in the acute coronary syndrome. Curr. Vasc. Pharmacol. 7, 367 373 (2009)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR13" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e574" 13 /a  /sup . Throughout life, melatonin levels tend to be significantly reduced. In the blood, once secreted from the pineal gland, melatonin is usually bound to albumin, metabolized to 6-hydroxymelatonin by cytochrome P-450 isoforms and conjugated, in the liver, to produce the principal urinary metabolite, 6-sulfatoxy-melatonin, which is finally eliminated through the kidney sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 14" title "Rosen, R. et al. Urinary 6-sulfatoxymelatonin level in age-related macular degeneration patients. Mol. Vis. 15, 1673 1679 (2009)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR14" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e579" 14 /a  /sup . However, melatonin is not exclusively produced in the pineal gland, but it is also locally synthesized in several cells and tissues, such as the retina, the gastrointestinal tract, and the innate immune system sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 10" title "Tan, D. X. et al. Identification of highly elevated levels of melatonin in bone marrow: its origin and significance. Biochim. Biophys. Acta 1472, 206 214 (1999)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR10" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e583" 10 /a  /sup . The synthesis in extrapineal sites presumably does not follow circadian rhythms, except for the retina, and mainly works as a local antioxidant sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 15" title "Acuna-Castroviejo, D. et al. Extrapineal melatonin: sources, regulation, and potential functions. Cell. Mol. Life Sci. 71, 2997 3025 (2014)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR15" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e587" 15 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 16" title "Favero, G., Franceschetti, L., Bonomini, F., Rodella, L. F.  amp; Rezzani, R. Melatonin as an anti-inflammatory agent modulating inflammasome activation. Int. J. Endocrinol. 2017, 1835195 (2017)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR16" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e590" 16 /a  /sup . /p  p Studies have proposed that mitochondria are the primary sites of melatonin synthesis sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 17" title "Manchester, L. C. et al. Melatonin: an ancient molecule that makes oxygen metabolically tolerable. J. Pineal Res. 59, 403 419 (2015)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR17" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e597" 17 /a  /sup . Mitochondria are major sources of free radicals, and in addition to being commonly used to treat disoriented circadian clocks due to jet lag and other disturbances (i.e., sleep inefficiency) sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 18" title "Karasek, M. Melatonin, human aging, and age-related diseases. Exp. Gerontol. 39, 1723 1729 (2004)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR18" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e601" 18 /a  /sup , melatonin has been widely used as an antioxidative therapy sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 19" title "Leaw, B. et al. Mitochondria, bioenergetics and excitotoxicity: new therapeutic targets in perinatal brain injury. Front. Cell. Neurosci. 11, 199 (2017)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR19" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e605" 19 /a  /sup  and its use dates back to 1993 (refs.  sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 20" title "Poeggeler, B., Reiter, R. J., Tan, D. X., Chen, L. D.  amp; Manchester, L. C. Melatonin, hydroxyl radical-mediated oxidative damage, and aging: a hypothesis. J. Pineal Res. 14, 151 168 (1993)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR20" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e609" 20 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 21" title "Tan, D. X. et al. Mitochondria and chloroplasts as the original sites of melatonin synthesis: a hypothesis related to melatonin s primary function and evolution in eukaryotes. J. Pineal Res. 54, 127 138 (2013)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR21" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e612" 21 /a  /sup ). The direct antioxidant and free radical scavenging properties of melatonin are mainly due to its electron-rich aromatic indole ring, which makes it a potent electron donor that can significantly reduce oxidative stress sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 3" title "Tan, D. X., Manchester, L. C., Esteban-Zubero, E., Zhou, Z.  amp; Reiter, R. J. Melatonin as a potent and inducible endogenous antioxidant: synthesis and metabolism. Molecules 20, 18886 18906 (2015)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR3" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e616" 3 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 22" title "Martinez, G. R. et al. Measurement of melatonin and its metabolites: importance for the evaluation of their biological roles. Endocrine 27, 111 118 (2005)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR22" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e619" 22 /a  /sup . Over this direct action, melatonin can further activate melatonin (MT) 1 and MT2 receptors (Fig.  a data-track "click" data-track-label "link" data-track-action "figure anchor" href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 Fig1" 1 /a ), upregulating antioxidative defensive systems by increasing the expression or activity of antioxidant enzymes such as superoxide dismutase and glutathione peroxidase sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 23" title "Tomas-Zapico, C.  amp; Coto-Montes, A. A proposed mechanism to explain the stimulatory effect of melatonin on antioxidative enzymes. J. Pineal Res. 39, 99 104 (2005)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR23" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e627" 23 /a  /sup . /p  div class "c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test "figure" data-container-section "figure" id "figure-1" data-title "Mechanisms of action of melatonin."  figure  figcaption  b id "Fig1" class "c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test "figure-caption-text" Fig. 1: Mechanisms of action of melatonin. /b  /figcaption  div class "c-article-section__figure-content"  div class "c-article-section__figure-item"  a class "c-article-section__figure-link" data-test "img-link" data-track "click" data-track-label "image" data-track-action "view figure" href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7/figures/1" rel "nofollow"  picture  source type "image/webp" srcset "//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art 3A10.1038 2Fs41419-019-1556-7/MediaObjects/41419_2019_1556_Fig1_HTML.png?as webp"  img aria-describedby "Fig1" src "//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art 3A10.1038 2Fs41419-019-1556-7/MediaObjects/41419_2019_1556_Fig1_HTML.png" alt "figure 1" loading "lazy" width "685" height "594"  /picture  /a  /div  div class "c-article-section__figure-description" data-test "bottom-caption" id "figure-1-desc"  p Melatonin can exert its effects by acting through receptor-independent mechanisms, which involve the direct interaction of melatonin and other molecules, and they are mainly related to its antioxidant and radical scavenging action ( b a /b ). As any other hormone, melatonin can also act through specific cellular receptors, by membrane melatonin receptors, called MT1 and MT2, which are seven transmembrane-spanning proteins belonging to the G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) superfamily, by the cytosolic enzyme QR2 (also called MT3), or through the nuclear receptors RZR/ROR ( b b /b ) /p  /div  /div  div class "u-text-right u-hide-print"  a class "c-article__pill-button" data-test "article-link" data-track "click" data-track-label "button" data-track-action "view figure" href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7/figures/1" data-track-dest "link:Figure1 Full size image" aria-label "Full size image figure 1" rel "nofollow"  span Full size image /span  svg width "16" height "16" focusable "false" role "img" aria-hidden "true" class "u-icon"  use xmlns:xlink "http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href " icon-eds-i-chevron-right-small"  /use  /svg  /a  /div  /figure  /div  p MT1 and MT2 are seven transmembrane-spanning proteins belonging to the G-protein-coupled receptor (GPCR) superfamily sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 24" title "Reppert, S. M. Melatonin receptors: molecular biology of a new family of G protein-coupled receptors. J. Biol. Rhythms 12, 528 531 (1997)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR24" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e660" 24 /a  /sup , which exhibit high-affinity binding and could be activated at low concentrations of melatonin (pM nM) sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 25" title "Jockers, R. et al. Update on melatonin receptors: IUPHAR Review 20. Br. J. Pharmacol. 173, 2702 2725 (2016)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR25" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e664" 25 /a  /sup . Furthermore, a third melatonin-binding site (MT3) has been characterized and identified as the cytosolic enzyme quinone reductase 2 (QR2), a known detoxifying enzyme that reduces menadione and other quinones sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 26" title "Boutin, J. A. Quinone reductase 2 as a promising target of melatonin therapeutic actions. Expert. Opin. Ther. Targets. 20, 303 317 (2016)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR26" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e668" 26 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 27" title "Dubocovich, M. L., Rivera-Bermudez, M. A., Gerdin, M. J.  amp; Masana, M. I. Molecular pharmacology, regulation and function of mammalian melatonin receptors. Front. Biosci. 8, d1093 d1108 (2003)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR27" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e671" 27 /a  /sup . Moreover, melatonin is also a ligand for nuclear receptors, such as retinoid orphan receptors (or retinoid Z receptors), ROR/RZR, and ROR/RZR sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" title "Becker-Andre, M. et al. Pineal gland hormone melatonin binds and activates an orphan of the nuclear receptor superfamily. J. Biol. Chem. 269, 28531 28534 (1994)." href " ref-CR28" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e675" 28 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" title "Dubocovich, M. L. et al. International Union of Basic and Clinical Pharmacology. LXXV. Nomenclature, classification, and pharmacology of G protein-coupled melatonin receptors. Pharmacol. Rev. 62, 343 380 (2010)." href " ref-CR29" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e675_1" 29 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 30" title "Paparrigopoulos, T. et al. Melatonin response to clonidine administration in depression: indication of presynaptic alpha2-adrenoceptor dysfunction. J. Affect. Disord. 65, 307 313 (2001)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR30" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e678" 30 /a  /sup  (Fig.  a data-track "click" data-track-label "link" data-track-action "figure anchor" href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 Fig1" 1 /a ). /p  /div  /div  /section  section data-title "Pathophysiological processes where melatonin plays important roles"  div class "c-article-section" id "Sec4-section"  h2 class "c-article-section__title js-section-title js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id "Sec4" Pathophysiological processes where melatonin plays important roles /h2  div class "c-article-section__content" id "Sec4-content"  h3 class "c-article__sub-heading" id "Sec5" Antiapoptotic activity /h3  p Almost all the studies that monitored the melatonin-dependent antiapoptotic activities include disease models characterized by the presence of a hypoxic ischemia (HI) event. HI describes a pathological condition in which an organ is subjected to harmful reduction in oxygen levels (hypoxia) and a deficit in blood supply (ischemia). This clinical picture entails the activation of several different pathways, and melatonin is known to modulate most of them, especially cell death. Mitochondria are organelles with key functions in the adaptive and maladaptive responses to brain injury sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 31" title "Raefsky, S. M.  amp; Mattson, M. P. Adaptive responses of neuronal mitochondria to bioenergetic challenges: Roles in neuroplasticity and disease resistance. Free Radic. Biol. Med. 102, 203 216 (2017)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR31" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e697" 31 /a  /sup ; indeed, they are strongly involved in cell death pathways, such as apoptosis, necrosis, and autophagy sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 32" title "Galluzzi, L. et al. Molecular mechanisms of cell death: recommendations of the Nomenclature Committee on Cell Death 2018. Cell Death. Differ. 25, 486 541 (2018)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR32" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e701" 32 /a  /sup , which cause an important portion of neuronal damage in the perinatal HI event (Fig.  a data-track "click" data-track-label "link" data-track-action "figure anchor" href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 Fig2" 2 /a ). In vitro experiments and neonatal animal models of HI suggested a very complex network of cell death cascades, highlighting a continuum from apoptosis to necrosis sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 33" title "Carloni, S., Carnevali, A., Cimino, M.  amp; Balduini, W. Extended role of necrotic cell death after hypoxia-ischemia-induced neurodegeneration in the neonatal rat. Neurobiol. Dis. 27, 354 361 (2007)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR33" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e708" 33 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 34" title "Northington, F. J. et al. Failure to complete apoptosis following neonatal hypoxia-ischemiamanifests as   34;continuum  34; phenotype of cell death and occurs with multiple manifestations of mitochondrial dysfunction in rodent forebrain. Neuroscience 149, 822 833 (2007)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR34" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e711" 34 /a  /sup . In other words, the coexistence of necrotic and apoptotic markers inside the same cell shape a heterogeneous phenotype characterized by a mixture of suicide program activation sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 33" title "Carloni, S., Carnevali, A., Cimino, M.  amp; Balduini, W. Extended role of necrotic cell death after hypoxia-ischemia-induced neurodegeneration in the neonatal rat. Neurobiol. Dis. 27, 354 361 (2007)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR33" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e715" 33 /a  /sup . In the immature brain of rodents, the cell death continuum is more switched versus apoptosis; indeed, HI drives cell death through Bcl-2 family members sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 35" title "Lok, J.  amp; Martin, L. J. Rapid subcellular redistribution of Bax precedes caspase-3 and endonuclease activation during excitotoxic neuronal apoptosis in rat brain. J. Neurotrauma 19, 815 828 (2002)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR35" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e720" 35 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 36" title "Morciano, G. et al. Intersection of mitochondrial fission and fusion machinery with apoptotic pathways: role of Mcl-1. Biol. Cell 108, 279 293 (2016)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR36" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e723" 36 /a  /sup . Under these conditions, mitochondria permeabilize, and proapoptotic factors, such as cytochrome  i c /i  (Cyt  i C /i ) and the apoptosis-inducing factor (AIF), are released into the cytosol. Melatonin administration reversed this phenotype by adopting a compensatory mechanism aimed at increasing Bcl-2 protein expression, blocking Bax proapoptotic activity via the SIRT1/NF-kB axis with a consequent and significant inhibition of Cyt  i C /i  release and the lack of apoptosome formation and caspase 3 activation sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 37" title "Sun, F. Y. et al. Neuroprotection by melatonin against ischemic neuronal injury associated with modulation of DNA damage and repair in the rat following a transient cerebral ischemia. J. Pineal Res. 33, 48 56 (2002)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR37" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e736" 37 /a  /sup  (Fig.  a data-track "click" data-track-label "link" data-track-action "figure anchor" href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 Fig2" 2 /a ). The AIF pathway, together with increased levels of cleaved caspase 3, is recognized as the main inductor of apoptosis in the damaged brain of neonatal rodents sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 38" title "Wang, X. et al. Caspase-3 activation after neonatal rat cerebral hypoxia-ischemia. Biol. Neonate 79, 172 179 (2001)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR38" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e744" 38 /a  /sup , even if their action becomes less pronounced once the brain matures sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 39" title "Hu, B. R., Liu, C. L., Ouyang, Y., Blomgren, K.  amp; Siesjo, B. K. Involvement of caspase-3 in cell death after hypoxia-ischemia declines during brain maturation. J. Cereb. Blood Flow Metab. 20, 1294 1300 (2000)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR39" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e748" 39 /a  /sup . Beneficial effects have also been reported by the use of melatonin in brain-injured mice 24 h after reperfusion with a selective action involving caspases 3 inhibition sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 40" title "Kilic, E., Kilic, U., Yulug, B., Hermann, D. M.  amp; Reiter, R. J. Melatonin reduces disseminate neuronal death after mild focal ischemia in mice via inhibition of caspase-3 and is suitable as an add-on treatment to tissue-plasminogen activator. J. Pineal Res. 36, 171 176 (2004)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR40" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e752" 40 /a  /sup . Nevertheless, melatonin also contributes to antiapoptotic activities via the Akt axis by preventing the decrease in pAkt and pBad levels upon HI injury sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 41" title "Koh, P. O. Melatonin attenuates the focal cerebral ischemic injury by inhibiting the dissociation of pBad from 14-3-3. J. Pineal Res. 44, 101 106 (2008)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR41" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e756" 41 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 42" title "Lee, S. H. et al. Sustained activation of Akt by melatonin contributes to the protection against kainic acid-induced neuronal death in hippocampus. J. Pineal Res. 40, 79 85 (2006)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR42" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e759" 42 /a  /sup  (Fig.  a data-track "click" data-track-label "link" data-track-action "figure anchor" href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 Fig2" 2 /a ). /p  div class "c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test "figure" data-container-section "figure" id "figure-2" data-title "Antiapoptotic mechanisms operated by melatonin."  figure  figcaption  b id "Fig2" class "c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test "figure-caption-text" Fig. 2: Antiapoptotic mechanisms operated by melatonin. /b  /figcaption  div class "c-article-section__figure-content"  div class "c-article-section__figure-item"  a class "c-article-section__figure-link" data-test "img-link" data-track "click" data-track-label "image" data-track-action "view figure" href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7/figures/2" rel "nofollow"  picture  source type "image/webp" srcset "//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art 3A10.1038 2Fs41419-019-1556-7/MediaObjects/41419_2019_1556_Fig2_HTML.png?as webp"  img aria-describedby "Fig2" src "//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art 3A10.1038 2Fs41419-019-1556-7/MediaObjects/41419_2019_1556_Fig2_HTML.png" alt "figure 2" loading "lazy" width "685" height "428"  /picture  /a  /div  div class "c-article-section__figure-description" data-test "bottom-caption" id "figure-2-desc"  p Endogenous levels of melatonin and exogenous administration confer to injured cells protection from many cell death forms including apoptosis, necroptosis, mPTP-driven cell death, and autophagy. Melatonin is high cell permeable and its beneficial effects are mediated by both MT1/2-dependent and MT1/2-independent mechanisms. Once in the cytoplasm it blocks the Ripk3 cascade, Drp1 activation, and Bax-dependent cytochrome  i c /i  (Cyt.  i C /i ) release caused by external insults; as a result, the cell receives pro-survival signals. Melatonin localizes also in mitochondria where PEPT1/2 and GLUT channels are postulated to be new transporters of this hormone in the organelle. In mitochondria, melatonin modulates mitochondrial permeability transition pore (mPTP) opening and counteracts oxidative stress /p  /div  /div  div class "u-text-right u-hide-print"  a class "c-article__pill-button" data-test "article-link" data-track "click" data-track-label "button" data-track-action "view figure" href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7/figures/2" data-track-dest "link:Figure2 Full size image" aria-label "Full size image figure 2" rel "nofollow"  span Full size image /span  svg width "16" height "16" focusable "false" role "img" aria-hidden "true" class "u-icon"  use xmlns:xlink "http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href " icon-eds-i-chevron-right-small"  /use  /svg  /a  /div  /figure  /div  h3 class "c-article__sub-heading" id "Sec6" Modulation of the permeability transition pore /h3  p Studies have reported that mitochondria permeabilize due to the mitochondrial permeability transition pore (mPTP) opening, a pathophysiological event that, under favorable conditions, causes an increase in permeability of the inner mitochondrial membrane and leads to mitochondrial depolarization, swelling, and the activation of the apoptotic and necrotic pathways sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 43" title "Morciano, G. et al. Mechanistic role of mPTP in ischemia-reperfusion injury. Adv. Exp. Med. Biol. 982, 169 189 (2017)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR43" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e800" 43 /a  /sup ; for these reasons, mPTP is widely considered as the final step of cell demise sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 44" title "Morciano, G. et al. Molecular identity of the mitochondrial permeability transition pore and its role in ischemia-reperfusion injury. J. Mol. Cell. Cardiol. 78, 142 153 (2015)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR44" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e804" 44 /a  /sup . Even though the exact structure of the mPTP, as well as its assembly kinetics, is still unknown, interesting findings suggested that dissociation of F sub 1 /sub F sub O /sub  ATP synthase dimers sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 45" title "Bonora, M. et al. Mitochondrial permeability transition involves dissociation of F1FO ATP synthase dimers and C-ring conformation. EMBO Rep. 18, 1077 1089 (2017)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR45" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e812" 45 /a  /sup  and the c subunit pore-forming part sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 46" title "Bonora, M. et al. Role of the c subunit of the FO ATP synthase in mitochondrial permeability transition. Cell Cycle 12, 674 683 (2013)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR46" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e817" 46 /a  /sup  have an important role in mitochondrial permeability transition (mPT) and constitute a valid therapeutic approach in pathologies subjected to widespread cell death sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 47" title "Bonora, M. et al. Targeting mitochondria for cardiovascular disorders: therapeutic potential and obstacles. Nat. Rev. Cardiol 16, 33 55 (2018)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR47" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e821" 47 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 48" title "Morciano, G. et al. Discovery of novel 1,3,8-Triazaspiro[4.5]decane derivatives that target the c subunit of F1/FO-adenosine triphosphate (ATP) synthase for the treatment of reperfusion damage in myocardial infarction. J. Med. Chem. 61, 7131 7143 (2018)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR48" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e824" 48 /a  /sup . It is no coincidence that melatonin, in addition to having a plethora of beneficial effects, executes neuroprotection by modulating mPTP activity sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 49" title "Waseem, M., Tabassum, H.  amp; Parvez, S. Melatonin modulates permeability transition pore and 5-hydroxydecanoate induced KATP channel inhibition in isolated brain mitochondria. Mitochondrion 31, 1 8 (2016)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR49" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e828" 49 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 50" title "Zhou, H. et al. Inhibitory effect of melatonin on necroptosis via repressing the Ripk3-PGAM5-CypD-mPTP pathway attenuates cardiac microvascular ischemia-reperfusion injury. J. Pineal Res. 65, e12503 (2018)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR50" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e831" 50 /a  /sup . Indeed, melatonin is highly permeable to cell membranes and easily crosses the blood brain barrier sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 51" title "Yu, H., Dickson, E. J., Jung, S. R., Koh, D. S.  amp; Hille, B. High membrane permeability for melatonin. J. Gen. Physiol. 147, 63 76 (2016)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR51" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e835" 51 /a  /sup , ensuring a good therapeutic profile for brain diseases, and is also able to accumulate into mitochondria, probably via GLUT/SLC2A and PEPT1/2 carriers sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 52" title "Huo, X. et al. Human transporters, PEPT1/2, facilitate melatonin transportation into mitochondria of cancer cells: an implication of the therapeutic potential. J. Pineal Res. 62, e12390 (2017)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR52" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e839" 52 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 53" title "Mayo, J. C., Sainz, R. M., Gonzalez-Menendez, P., Hevia, D.  amp; Cernuda-Cernuda, R. Melatonin transport into mitochondria. Cell. Mol. Life. Sci. 74, 3927 3940 (2017)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR53" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e842" 53 /a  /sup . Studies have shown how its use in mitochondria isolated from rodent brains and subjected to Ca sup 2  /sup -induced mPTP conferred protection from mitochondrial swelling and membrane depolarization sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 49" title "Waseem, M., Tabassum, H.  amp; Parvez, S. Melatonin modulates permeability transition pore and 5-hydroxydecanoate induced KATP channel inhibition in isolated brain mitochondria. Bull. 64, 471 479 (2005)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR83" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1085" 83 /a  /sup , modulation of the central GABAergic system sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 84" title "Golombek, D. A., Pevet, P.  amp; Cardinali, D. P. Melatonin effects on behavior: possible mediation by the central GABAergic system. Neurosci. Biobehav. Rev. 20, 403 412 (1996)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR84" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1089" 84 /a  /sup , and additional interaction with multiple receptor types. Those ligand-target bindings would include benzodiazepine, opioid, (1)- and (2)-adrenergic, serotonergic and cholinergic receptors sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 85" title "Srinivasan, V. et al. Melatonin in antinociception: its therapeutic applications. Curr. Neuropharmacol. 10, 167 178 (2012)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR85" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1093" 85 /a  /sup  and, notably, the fascinating issue of the anti-nociceptive role of melatonin seems to be mediated by MT1 and MT2 receptors themselves sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 86" title "Srinivasan, V. et al. Potential use of melatonergic drugs in analgesia: mechanisms of action. Brain Res. Bull. 81, 362 371 (2010)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR86" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1097" 86 /a  /sup  sup , /sup  sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 87" title "Mantovani, M. et al. Mechanisms involved in the antinociception caused by melatonin in mice. J. Pineal Res. 41, 382 389 (2006)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR87" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1101" 87 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 88" title "Yu, C. X., Zhu, C. B., Xu, S. F., Cao, X. D.  amp; Wu, G. C. Selective MT(2) melatonin receptor antagonist blocks melatonin-induced antinociception in rats. Neurosci. Lett. 282, 161 164 (2000)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR88" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1104" 88 /a  /sup . Studies have postulated that the cause may be ascribed to the reduction in the excitability of pain transmitting dorsal horn neurons via hyperpolarization due to MT1/2-melatonin binding sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 89" title "Laurido, C. et al. Effect of melatonin on rat spinal cord nociceptive transmission. Neuroreport 13, 89 91 (2002)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR89" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1109" 89 /a  /sup . /p  p Among the effects provided by melatonin administration, the modulation of  i N /i -methyl- span class "u-small-caps" d /span -aspartate (NMDA) receptors and the conservation of myelin sheets in the central nervous system (CNS) are probably the least treated. NMDA receptors are sensitive to glutamate binding, the major excitatory neurotransmitter in the brain whose extracellular levels increase abnormally during insults, such as ischemia. Excessive release of glutamate and its binding with NMDA, -amino-3-hydroxy-5-methyl-4-isoxazolepropionic acid (AMPA), or kainite (KA) receptors promotes excitotoxicity cell injury with a consequent activation of many molecular pathways, resulting in intracellular calcium (Ca sup 2  /sup ) overload sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 90" title "Giorgi, C., Marchi, S.  amp; Pinton, P. Publisher Correction: The machineries, regulation and cellular functions of mitochondrial calcium. Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell Biol. 19, 746 (2018)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR90" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1124" 90 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 91" title "Giorgi, C., Danese, A., Missiroli, S., Patergnani, S.  amp; Pinton, P. Calcium dynamics as a machine for decoding signals. Trends Cell Biol. 28, 258 273 (2018)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR91" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1127" 91 /a  /sup , reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, mPT, and cell swelling with brain edema sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 92" title "Arundine, M.  amp; Tymianski, M. Molecular mechanisms of calcium-dependent neurodegeneration in excitotoxicity. Cell Calcium 34, 325 337 (2003)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR92" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1131" 92 /a  /sup . Patch-clamp experiments demonstrated how melatonin is able to modulate NMDA receptor activity by the drastic attenuation of their currents in neurons located in the spinal cord dorsal horn sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 93" title "Wang, S. et al. Exacerbated mechanical hyperalgesia in rats with genetically predisposed depressive behavior: role of melatonin and NMDA receptors. Pain 153, 2448 2457 (2012)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR93" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1136" 93 /a  /sup . Focused experiments conducted in rat striatum synaptosome preparations have reported that melatonin inhibits the excitatory response in a partially Ca sup 2  /sup -dependent manner in which the direct effect on membrane hyperpolarization promoted intracellular Ca sup 2  /sup  influx reduction sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 94" title "Escames, G. et al. Calcium-dependent effects of melatonin inhibition of glutamatergic response in rat striatum. J. Neuroendocrinol. 13, 459 466 (2001)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR94" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1144" 94 /a  /sup . The involvement of melatonin is dose-dependent, and if at physiological concentrations, it inhibited NMDA-induced current. At higher dosages, it also participated in the modulation of AMPA-glutamate binding. It follows that melatonin exerts powerful protective mechanisms against oxidative damage and excitotoxicity mediated by glutamate receptors sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 95" title "Kim, H. J.  amp; Kwon, J. S. Effects of placing micro-implants of melatonin in striatum on oxidative stress and neuronal damage mediated by N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) and non-NMDA receptors. Arch. Pharm. Res. 22, 35 43 (1999)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR95" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1148" 95 /a  /sup . /p  p Melatonin as a neuroprotective agent was also recommended in those pathologies involving white matter damage sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 96" title "Olivier, P. et al. Melatonin promotes oligodendroglial maturation of injured white matter in neonatal rats. PLoS ONE 4, e7128 (2009)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR96" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1155" 96 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 97" title "Padilla-Gomes, N. F. et al. Prevalence of neonatal ultrasound brain lesions in premature infants with and without intrauterine growth restriction. Acta Paediatr. 96, 1582 1587 (2007)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR97" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1158" 97 /a  /sup . Indeed, researchers have reported a plethora of positive effects with different exposures of melatonin following CNS trauma, such as axonal regrowth and sprouting, conservation of a given thickness of myelin sheet in oligodendrocytes, and improved nerve maturation sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 96" title "Olivier, P. et al. Melatonin promotes oligodendroglial maturation of injured white matter in neonatal rats. PLoS ONE 4, e7128 (2009)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR96" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1162" 96 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 97" title "Padilla-Gomes, N. F. et al. Prevalence of neonatal ultrasound brain lesions in premature infants with and without intrauterine growth restriction. Acta Paediatr. 96, 1582 1587 (2007)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR97" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1165" 97 /a  /sup . /p  p As reported in the previous paragraphs, melatonin is a widespread potent molecule that can reduce cellular damage. Melatonin has recently received increased attention for its enormous potential in a wide range of different pathologies. In the next section, we discuss the use of melatonin for newborn care. /p  /div  /div  /section  section data-title "Clinical utility in newborns"  div class "c-article-section" id "Sec10-section"  h2 class "c-article-section__title js-section-title js-c-reading-companion-sections-item" id "Sec10" Clinical utility in newborns /h2  div class "c-article-section__content" id "Sec10-content"  p Oxidative stress has a leading role in the spectrum of neonatal disease processes, and it has been known for more than 160 years that hyperoxia has toxic effects on different organs. Saugstad sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 98" title "Saugstad, O. D. Oxidative stress in the newborn a 30-year perspective. Biol. Neonate 88, 228 236 (2005)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR98" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1181" 98 /a  /sup  in 2005 talked about the  oxygen radical disease of the newborn : oxidative stress may involve different organs, often simultaneously, giving rise to different signs and different clinical manifestations. /p  p Babies at birth are naturally exposed to the hyperoxic challenge due to the transition from the hypoxic intrauterine environment (pO sub 2 /sub  of 20 25 mmHg) to extrauterine life (pO sub 2 /sub  of 100 mmHg). This transition naturally increases oxidative stress, but the gap is even more significant for infants that require resuscitation at birth with supplemental oxygen. Newborns are often exposed to oxygen therapies, have low antioxidant defenses despite high levels of toxic radicals, and are more susceptible to infections, especially if born prematurely sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 99" title "Saugstad, O. D., Sejersted, Y., Solberg, R., Wollen, E. J.  amp; Bjoras, M. Oxygenation of the newborn: a molecular approach. Neonatology 101, 315 325 (2012)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR99" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1192" 99 /a  /sup . Furthermore, inflammation is strictly correlated with oxidative stress in many conditions that affect newborns. To counteract free radical damage, therapeutic strategies in preclinical and clinical trials have tried to increase the antioxidant status of term and preterm infants, and melatonin, which is safe, nontoxic, and effective, has developed a leading role. Indeed, the efficacy of melatonin has been tested against the  oxygen radical diseases of newborn , giving promising results sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" title "Chen, Y. C., Tain, Y. L., Sheen, J. M.  amp; Huang, L. T. Melatonin utility in neonates and children. J. Formos Med. Assoc. 111, 57 66 (2012)." href " ref-CR100" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1196" 100 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" title "Gitto, E. et al. Protective role of melatonin in neonatal diseases. Oxid. Med. Cell. Longev. 2013, 980374 (2013)." href " ref-CR101" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1196_1" 101 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 102" title "McKenna, H.  amp; Reiss, I. K. M. The case for a chronobiological approach to neonatal care. Early Hum. Dev. 126, 1 5 (2018)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR102" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1199" 102 /a  /sup  (Fig.  a data-track "click" data-track-label "link" data-track-action "figure anchor" href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 Fig4" 4 /a ). /p  div class "c-article-section__figure js-c-reading-companion-figures-item" data-test "figure" data-container-section "figure" id "figure-4" data-title "Clinical trial of melatonin in newborn care."  figure  figcaption  b id "Fig4" class "c-article-section__figure-caption" data-test "figure-caption-text" Fig. 4: Clinical trial of melatonin in newborn care. /b  /figcaption  div class "c-article-section__figure-content"  div class "c-article-section__figure-item"  a class "c-article-section__figure-link" data-test "img-link" data-track "click" data-track-label "image" data-track-action "view figure" href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7/figures/4" rel "nofollow"  picture  source type "image/webp" srcset "//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art 3A10.1038 2Fs41419-019-1556-7/MediaObjects/41419_2019_1556_Fig4_HTML.png?as webp"  img aria-describedby "Fig4" src "//media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art 3A10.1038 2Fs41419-019-1556-7/MediaObjects/41419_2019_1556_Fig4_HTML.png" alt "figure 4" loading "lazy" width "685" height "545"  /picture  /a  /div  div class "c-article-section__figure-description" data-test "bottom-caption" id "figure-4-desc"  p Melatonin clinical trial in full term infants (blue), in preterm pathologies (purple) or both (green). In yellow are reported studies of pharmacokinetic. HIE hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy, IUGR intrauterine growth retardation, CLD chronic lung disease, PVL periventricular leukomalcia /p  /div  /div  div class "u-text-right u-hide-print"  a class "c-article__pill-button" data-test "article-link" data-track "click" data-track-label "button" data-track-action "view figure" href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7/figures/4" data-track-dest "link:Figure4 Full size image" aria-label "Full size image figure 4" rel "nofollow"  span Full size image /span  svg width "16" height "16" focusable "false" role "img" aria-hidden "true" class "u-icon"  use xmlns:xlink "http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xlink:href " icon-eds-i-chevron-right-small"  /use  /svg  /a  /div  /figure  /div  h3 class "c-article__sub-heading" id "Sec11" Melatonin and sepsis /h3  p Sepsis is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in newborns, born both preterm and at term, with an incidence of 1 10 cases per 1000 live births and a mortality rate as high as 20  observed in very preterm newborns sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 103" title "Poggi, C.  amp; Dani, C. Sepsis and oxidative stress in the newborn: from pathogenesis to novel therapeutic targets. Oxid. Med. Cell. Longev 2018, 9390140 (2018)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR103" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1233" 103 /a  /sup . Although improvements in neonatal care have decreased the impact of early-onset sepsis in term infants, preterm babies remain at high risk for both early-onset and late-onset sepsis and their sequelae. According to the guidelines of the International Pediatric Sepsis Consensus Conference sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 104" title "de Souza, D. C., Brandao, M. B.  amp; Piva, J. P. From the International Pediatric Sepsis Conference 2005 to the Sepsis-3 Consensus. Rev. Bras. Ter. Intensiva. 30, 1 5 (2018)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR104" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1237" 104 /a  /sup , neonatal sepsis is defined as a clinical syndrome characterized by the presence of both infection and systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) and can cause severe neurological complications due to brain infection, as well as secondary hypoxemia resulting from septic shock, pulmonary hypertension and severe lung disease. /p  p Clinically, SIRS includes respiratory symptoms, ranging in severity from mild tachypnea to respiratory failure, persistent pulmonary hypertension, irritability, lethargy, temperature instability, poor perfusion and hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagulation, poor feeding, vomiting and ileus. CNS involvement may presents with seizures, apnea, and depressed sensorium. It is accepted that bacterial infection induces sepsis via the production of endotoxins and the process is maintained by the inflammatory cascade and oxidative mechanisms that, once activated, operate independently from the presence of pathogens sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 103" title "Poggi, C.  amp; Dani, C. Sepsis and oxidative stress in the newborn: from pathogenesis to novel therapeutic targets. Oxid. Med. Cell. Longev 2018, 9390140 (2018)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR103" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1244" 103 /a  /sup . Intracellular redox changes are involved in the neonatal sepsis redox cycle and represent the main cause of cell dysfunction and mitochondria. As reported by Bajeti et al. in 2014 (ref.  sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 105" title "Bajcetic, M., Spasic, S.  amp; Spasojevic, I. Redox therapy in neonatal sepsis: reasons, targets, strategy, and agents. Shock 42, 179 184 (2014)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR105" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1248" 105 /a  /sup ), the immature innate immune system in neonates has a low capacity to generate ROS, so pro-oxidative processes in neonatal sepsis are limited to intracellular compartments of affected tissues. Moreover, neonatal cells appear to compensate for the infection-dependent mitochondrial dysfunction by extramitochondrial ATP production, and proliferating cells are particularly susceptible to apoptosis induced by oxidative stress sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 105" title "Bajcetic, M., Spasic, S.  amp; Spasojevic, I. Redox therapy in neonatal sepsis: reasons, targets, strategy, and agents. Shock 42, 179 184 (2014)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR105" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1252" 105 /a  /sup . This explains a higher incidence of long-term effects in neonatal sepsis survivors but also underlines the importance of different strategies for sepsis treatment both with antioxidant administration and pharmacologic inhibition of pro-oxidant pathways in addition to antibiotics. /p  p Endogenous blood melatonin concentrations are higher in newborns with late-onset sepsis sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 106" title "El-Mashad, A. R., Elmahdy, H., El-Dib, M., Elbatch, M.  amp; Aly, H. Can melatonin be used as a marker for neonatal sepsis? J. Matern. Fetal Neonatal Med. 29, 2870 2873 (2016)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR106" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1259" 106 /a  /sup , and its use as an adjuvant therapy in the treatment of sepsis is associated with improvement of clinical and laboratory outcomes sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 107" title "El Frargy, M., El-Sharkawy, H. M.  amp; Attia, G. F. Use of melatonin as an adjuvant therapy in neonatal sepsis. J. Neonatal Perinatal Med. 8, 227 232 (2015)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR107" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1263" 107 /a  /sup . In 2018, El-Gendy et al. sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 108" title "El-Gendy, F. M., El-Hawy, M. A.  amp; Hassan, M. G. Beneficial effect of melatonin in the treatment of neonatal sepsis. J. Matern. Fetal Neonatal Med. 31, 2299 2303 (2018)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR108" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1267" 108 /a  /sup  published a study about the beneficial effect of melatonin in the treatment of neonatal sepsis that involved 40 septic neonates and concluded that the group who received melatonin had a significant improvement in clinical condition and serum parameters compared with the control group. /p  p The review and meta-analysis of Henderson et al. enrolled 120 ill newborns from three different studies who were treated with melatonin as adjunctive therapies for sepsis. The results revealed statistically significant mean differences in C-reactive protein serum levels between groups at 24 h postadjunctive therapy with melatonin and a significant improvement of clinical condition in neonates from the intervention group compared to the control group within 3 days of therapy sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 109" title "Henderson, R., Kim, S.  amp; Lee, E. Use of melatonin as adjunctive therapy in neonatal sepsis: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Complement. Ther. Med. 39, 131 136 (2018)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR109" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1274" 109 /a  /sup . Based on clinicaltrial.gov, the recruitment phase of a randomized study aimed to assess the efficacy of melatonin as an adjuvant in the treatment of free radicals in septic preterm infants compared to the conventional approach alone was completed in Egypt (NCT03295162). /p  p In conclusion, the use of melatonin as an adjunctive therapy for sepsis treatment significantly reduced inflammatory biomarkers and improved clinical conditions in neonates, but larger scale studies with higher validity are needed to demonstrate clear clinical benefits of the therapy sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 103" title "Poggi, C.  amp; Dani, C. Sepsis and oxidative stress in the newborn: from pathogenesis to novel therapeutic targets. Oxid. Med. Cell. Longev 2018, 9390140 (2018)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR103" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1282" 103 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 105" title "Bajcetic, M., Spasic, S.  amp; Spasojevic, I. Redox therapy in neonatal sepsis: reasons, targets, strategy, and agents. PRIMELIP, a multicenter therapeutic trial (NCT02395783), tested its neuroprotective action when administered in the immediate prepartum period in very preterm infants. /p  h3 class "c-article__sub-heading" id "Sec14" Chronic lung disease /h3  p BPD, also known as CLD, is an important cause of respiratory illness in preterm newborns that results in significant morbidity and mortality. The epidemiology and pathology of BPD have changed over the past 50 years.  Old  BPD occurred in preterm infants with surfactant deficiency following respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). These infants required ventilatory support and high concentrations of supplemental oxygen therapies that induced lung damage with regions of atelectasis and regions of hyperinflation, epithelial injury, hyperplasia of airway smooth muscle, fibrosis, and pulmonary vascular hypertension. The improvement of neonatal RDS management as surfactant administration, antenatal glucocorticoid therapy, and less aggressive mechanical ventilation significantly decreased the morbidity and mortality of RDS and BPD in this population, shifting the demographics of BPD to earlier preterm infants ( lt;29 weeks GA). As a consequence  new  BPD occurred at extremely low GA and is characterized by arrested alveolar-capillary development with larger, simplified alveoli; increased interstitial fibrosis and abnormal pulmonary vasculature; increased permeability with immature mechanisms for clearance of lung liquid; and recruitment of macrophages and neutrophils. These extremely low GA infants may not have surfactant deficiency or RDS but instead have early requirements for oxygen and ventilatory support due to multiple factors leading to  respiratory instability of prematurity  sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" title "Aschner, J. L., Bancalari, E. H.  amp; McEvoy, C. T. Can we prevent bronchopulmonary dysplasia? J. Pediatr. 189, 26 30 (2017)." href " ref-CR127" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1388" 127 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" title "Voynow, J. A.  New  bronchopulmonary dysplasia and chronic lung disease. Paediatr. Respir. Rev. 24, 17 18 (2017)." href " ref-CR128" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1388_1" 128 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 129" title "Poggi, C.  amp; Dani, C. Antioxidant strategies and respiratory disease of the preterm newborn: an update. Oxid. Med. Cell Longev. 2014, 721043 (2014)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR129" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1391" 129 /a  /sup . The management of RDS includes the prevention of hypoxemia and acidosis, the optimization of fluid management, the reduction in metabolic demands, the prevention of lung atelectasis and pulmonary edema, the reduction in lung damage due to aggressive mechanical ventilation, and the use of antioxidant strategies to minimize oxidant lung injury. Several investigators have reported that aggressive ventilatory strategies and oxygen therapy are the most important risk factors for lung disease. If oxygen radical-damaged tissues are present the premature lung is deficient in its antioxidant capacity. It follows that after oxygen injury, the inflammatory reaction develops, and IL1-, IL-6, TNF- and IL-8 are found in higher concentrations in babies who developed CLD sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 130" title "Gitto, E. et al. Pineal Res. 36, 250 255 (2004)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR130" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1395" 130 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 131" title "Gitto, E. et al. The authors concluded that melatonin treatment reduced proinflammatory cytokines in tracheobronchial aspirate, serum nitrite/nitare levels, and improved outcome because of its antioxidative actions sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 130" title "Gitto, E. et al. Pineal Res. 39, 287 293 (2005)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR131" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1416" 131 /a  /sup . Further studies are needed to investigate the possible use of melatonin as a preventive strategy of oxidative stress in preterm newborns. Thus, the preliminary results, i.e., the safety profile with high feasibility of administration, make melatonin a promising therapy for the prevention of BPD. /p  h3 class "c-article__sub-heading" id "Sec15" Melatonin and asphyxiated term infants /h3  p Perinatal asphyxia refers to a condition during labor in which impaired gas exchange leads to fetal hypoxemia and hypercarbia. It is identified by fetal acidosis as pH  lt; 7.0 and it is used in association with the neurological signs to evaluate term newborn at risk for brain injury in the perinatal period. The frequency of perinatal asphyxia is approximately 2 3/1000 live births sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 133" title "Yildiz, E. P., Ekici, B.  amp; Tatli, B. Neonatal hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy: an update on disease pathogenesis and treatment. Expert Rev. Neurother. 17, 449 459 (2017)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR133" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1428" 133 /a  /sup . The neurodevelopmental consequences of brain injury include death, cerebral palsy, severe intellectual disabilities, blindness, deafness, and a number of minor behavioral and cognitive deficits. HI can develop acutely or chronically during the prenatal (maternal factors such as hypotension, infection, hypoxia), perinatal (umbilical cord accidents, uterine rupture, placental factors), or postnatal period (shock, anemia, respiratory, or cardiac arrest) sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 134" title "Martinello, K., Hart, A. R., Yap, S., Mitra, S.  amp; Robertson, N. J. Management and investigation of neonatal encephalopathy: 2017 update. Arch. Dis. Child Fetal Neonatal Ed. 102, F346 F358 (2017)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR134" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1432" 134 /a  /sup . /p  p In the pathological changes of neonatal HI encephalopathy (HIE), the time of injury and the time of treatment play an important role because of the cascading reaction process and cell changes. According to Wang, based on significant differences in the pathophysiology and biochemistry of brain tissues, it is possible to divide HIE into three phases, all of which have apoptosis or necrosis of nerve cells as the final outcome of brain damage sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 135" title "Hassell, K. J., Ezzati, M., Alonso-Alconada, D., Hausenloy, D. J.  amp; Robertson, N. J. New horizons for newborn brain protection: enhancing endogenous neuroprotection. Arch. Dis. Child Fetal Neonatal Ed. 100, F541 F552 (2015)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR135" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1439" 135 /a , a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 136" title "Wang, Q., Lv, H., Lu, L., Ren, P.  amp; Li, L. Neonatal hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy: emerging therapeutic strategies based on pathophysiologic phases of the injury. J. Matern. Fetal Neonatal Med., 2, 1 8 (2018)." href "/articles/s41419-019-1556-7 ref-CR136" id "ref-link-section-d343505861e1442" 136 /a  /sup . /p  p The primary energy failure phase (phase I) occurs 0 6 h after HI injury. Because of hypoxia and acidosis in tissues and organs, reduced myocardial contractility, decreased arterial blood pressure, and reduced cerebral blood flow, some cells undergo primary death based on the severity and duration of HI. Clinically, the treatment strategies during phase I utilize conventional methods: patients should be treated with hypothermia, free radical scavengers (e.g., melatonin, erythropoietin, coenzyme Q10), excitatory amino acid receptor blocking agents, and/or neuroprotective agents. /p  p The secondary energy failure phase (phase II) occurs 6 72 h after HI, and the deterioration of oxidative metabolism has a leading role. Despite adequate oxygenation and circulation, excitatory neurotransmitters and free radicals continue to be released, phosphorus reserves are depleted, inflammatory factors are involved, and brain injury is substantial; as the time progresses, nerve cell apoptosis begins. This phase is marked by the onset of seizures, secondary to excitotoxic edema, cytokine accumulation, and more serious mitochondrial dysfunction. Therefore, the treatment strategies during phase II follow the treatments employed during phase I: babies should be treated with anti-inflammatory, neuroprotective, or nerve regenerating agents (e.g., nerve growth factor), and stem cell transplantation. /p  p The injury repair or chronic inflammation phase (phase III) occurs days, months, and years after HI insult. Based on the severity of the disease, the duration of HI and the effects of prior therapeutic interventions, there are generally two outcomes: one involves recovery, where the damaged brain tissue enters the repair process and the surviving neurons and glial cells begin to differentiate, proliferate, and regenerate; in the other outcome, the injured tissue continues to deteriorate, and the mechanism of the persisting damage involves gliosis with the loss of support of neurotrophic factors, persistent inflammatory receptor activation, and changes in microglia and astrocytes that continue to release harmful cytokines, which promote neuronal death and axonal injury. Even in this case, the treatment should include anti-inflammatory agents, neuroprotective agents, or nerve regenerating agents (e.g., nerve growth factor) and stem cell transplantation. Once the patient s condition has stabilized, a rehabilitation program should be planned for the patient as early as possible sup  a data-track "click" data-track-action "reference anchor" data-track-label "link" data-test "citation-ref" aria-label "Reference 135" title "Hassell, K.
